definition:
The *extended real numbers* are the real numbers together with $+\infty$
(or simply $\infty$) and $-\infty$. This set is usually denoted by
$\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$ or $[-\infty,\,\infty]$, and the elements
$+\infty$ and $-\infty$ are called *plus* and *minus infinity*,
respectively. (N.B., “$\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$” may sometimes the
algebraic closure of $\mathbb{R}$; see the special notations in
algebra.)

The real numbers are in certain contexts called [*finite*]{} as contrast
to $\infty$.

### Order on $\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$

The relation on ${\mathbb{R}}$ extends to $\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$ by
defining that for any $x\in {\mathbb{R}}$, we have $$\begin{aligned}
-\infty&<& x, \\
x &<& \infty,\end{aligned}$$ and that $-\infty < \infty$. For
$a\in{\mathbb{R}}$, let us also define intervals $$\begin{aligned}
(a,\,\infty{]} &=& \{x\in {\mathbb{R}}: x>a \}, \\
{[}{-\infty},\,a) &=& \{x\in {\mathbb{R}}: x<a \}.\end{aligned}$$

### Addition

For any real number $x$, we define $$\begin{aligned}
 x + (\pm\infty) &=& (\pm\infty) + x = \pm\infty,\end{aligned}$$ and for
$+\infty$ and $-\infty$, we define $$\begin{aligned}
(\pm \infty) + (\pm \infty) &=& \pm \infty.\end{aligned}$$ It should be
pointed out that sums like $(+\infty) + (-\infty)$ are left undefined.
Thus $\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$ is not an ordered ring although
${\mathbb{R}}$ is.

### Multiplication

If $x$ is a positive real number, then $$\begin{aligned}
 x \cdot (\pm \infty) &=& (\pm\infty)\cdot x  = \pm\infty.\end{aligned}$$
Similarly, if $x$ is a negative real number, then $$\begin{aligned}
 x \cdot (\pm \infty) &=& (\pm \infty)\cdot x = \mp\infty.\end{aligned}$$
Furthermore, for $\infty$ and $-\infty$, we define $$\begin{aligned}
(+\infty) \cdot(+\infty) &=& (-\infty)\cdot (-\infty) = +\infty, \\
(+\infty) \cdot (- \infty) &=& (-\infty)\cdot (+\infty) = -\infty. \end{aligned}$$

In many areas of mathematics, products like $0\cdot \infty$ are left
undefined. However, a special case is measure theory, where it is
convenient to define $$\begin{aligned}
0\cdot (\pm \infty) &=& (\pm \infty) \cdot 0 = 0.\end{aligned}$$

### Absolute value

For $\infty$ and $-\infty$, the absolute value is defined as
$$|\pm \infty| = +\infty.$$

### Topology

The topology of $\overline{R}$ is given by the usual base of
${\mathbb{R}}$ together with with intervals of type $[-\infty,\,a)$,
$(a,\,\infty]$. This makes $\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$ into a compact
topological space. $\overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$ can also be seen to be
homeomorphic to the interval $[-1,\,1]$, via the map
$x \mapsto (2/\pi) \arctan x$. Consequently, every continuous function
$f\colon \overline{{\mathbb{R}}}\to \overline{{\mathbb{R}}}$ has a
minimum and maximum.
